publicationStmt.p: Prepared for the Textual Communities system

sourceDesc.p: Exported from version 1 of Textual Communities

revisionDesc.change: Created on Friday 4 May 2018 by Peter Robinson (peter.robinson@usask.ca)

div.l: Ryght as it wer̉e astede of lumbardy
Þer to so horslye and so quikke of yee
As it agentil corsere poleyn̄ wer̉e
For Certes from his tayle vn to his ere
Nature nearte ne coude him not a mende
In noo degree as alle the peple wende
But eủermore her moste wondre it was
How that it coude goo and was of bras
It was of fᵉiery as alle þe peple wende
Diủerse Folke diủersely demid
As meny hedis as meny wittꝭes þẻre ben
Þei mormeden as doon a swarme of been
And made Skyllis aftir her fantesye
Rehersyng of the olde poetrye
And seide it was like the pigase
Þe hors that had wyngꝭes for to flee
Or ellꝭes it was the grekꝭes hors Synome
That browght the Grekis to distroccioun̄
As men in thes olde gestꝭes Rede
Myn herte quod on̄ is eủermore in drede
I trowe some men of armes ben þẻre in
That shape hem this Citee for to wynne
It wer͗e Right goode that/ alle suche thing wer͗e know
A noþẻre Rounde to his Felow lowe
And seyd he lyed for it was raþẻer like
An apparence made by some magyke
As iogoulours pleyn̄ at thes feestꝭes grete
Of sundry thoughtꝭes þus þei Iangille ⁊and trete
As lewde peple demen comynlye
Of thinges that ben made mor͗e subtelye
Then thei can in thei͗e lewdnenesse co͒mp̉rehende
They demen Gladly to þe badder͗ Ende
And some of hēm wonderid on̄ the myrroᵘur
Þat borne was vp into þe mastr͗e, towr͗e
How men myght in hit suche thingꝭes see
And oþẻre aunswerde and saide it myght wel be
Naturelly by composissioun̄
Of aungels and of sly for Refleccions
And saide that in Rome was suche one
Þei speke of Alcen̄ and of vetelon̄
And of Arestotle þat wryte in hir lyves
Of Queynte myrroᵘurs and prospecsatyses
As knowe þei þᵗat have her͗e bookes herde
And oþe͗re folke hathe wonderid on þe swerde
That wolde perishe thorow out eủery thinge/
And fel in speche of thelophus the kynge
And off Achilles for his queynte sper̉e
For he coude wᵗith hit boþe hele and der͗e
Ryght in suche wyse as men may wᵗith þe swerde
Of whiche Right nowe ye have yoᵘur selve harde
Þey speke of sundry hardynge of metalle
And speke of medecinis þẻre wᵗith aƚƚlle
And whan̄ and how it shulde hardid be
Whiche vnknowen algate is to me
Þoo speke Þei of Canaces Ringe
And saide al that suche a wond̉er thyng
Of crafte of Rynges harde þei neủer noon̄
Save that by moyses and kynge salamon̄
Had a man̉er connyng on̄ suche a mann̉er arte
Þus seyne the peple and drawen̄ hem a parte/
But netheles some seyden that it was
Wondre to make of Ferne glas

rdg.hi: And yit is glas nat lyk asshen of ferne

app.rdg: And yit is glas nat lyk asshen of ferne

div.l: þẻre fore sesithe hir Iangelynge ⁊and hir wondir
As for͗e wonderen̄ som̄ þe cause of þe þund͗e
On̄ Ebbe on̄ flode on̄ gossom̉er ⁊and on̄ myste
And on̄ althing til þe cause is wiste/
Thus Iaingelyn̄ þei demin̄ ⁊and devisen̄
Til that the kynge gan from the borde a Risen̄
Phebus hathe lefte the aungel meredionaƚƚ
And yitte assendyng was þe best Ryaƚƚ
Þe gentil lioun̄ wᵗith his Aldrian̄
When that þis tartre kyng Cambustan̄
Rose From̄ his borde þẻre he sat ful hihe
Be forne hīm gooþe the loude mynstrelsye
Til he come to his chambr͗e of par͗ementys
Þẻre as þei sownyn̄ diuers Instrumentꝭes
Þat is like an heven̄ for to her͗e
Now daunsen̄ lusty Venus childerin̄ der̉e
For in the Fysshe her ladye satte ful hihe
And lokeþe on hēm wᵗith a frendlye eye
This noble kynge is sette vpon̄ his trone
This staunge knyght is fet to hīm ful sone
And on̄ the davnce he goþe wᵗith Canace /
Þẻre is þe Reuel and þe Iolytee/
Þat is not able a dul man̄ to devise

He muste have knowe such of
such of love ⁊and his ʆseruice
And be a festlych man as Fressh as maye
Þat shulle yewe deuisen suche a raye
Whoo coude yowe telle þe Forme of daunces
So vncouthe ⁊and so Fresshe countenauns
And þẻre to suche subtely lokynges
Fro drede of Ielowse of menꝭes preysinges
No man but launcelot /and he is dede/
Þẻre for I pas oủer alle þis lusty hede/
I sey nomor͗e but in this Iolynes

He lete hem too too
men to soꝑper hem dresse /
Þe Styward bid Spicꝭes for to hye
And eke the wyne in alle þis melodye/
The vsshers and þe Squiers ben goon̄
The Spices and þe wyne ben come anon̄
They Ete and dronke ⁊and when þⁱˢ was at a Ende
Into the temple as Reson̄ was they wende
Þe service do þey solempnely that daye
What nedeþe to Reherse her̉e þẻre araye/
Eche man wot welle that a kyngꝭes feste
Hathe plente to þe moste ⁊and þe leste
